qas.question: Voltage opposing the motor supply voltage is called what?

answers.text: the running speed of the motor

qas.question: Voltage at the brushes is equal to what?

answers.text: back emf of the motor, plus the voltage drop across the winding internal resistance

qas.question: If load increases, what happens to current drawn?

answers.text: more current is drawn from the supply

qas.question: Voltage not opposing the motor supply voltage is called what?

plausible_answers.text: back emf results, and more current is drawn from the supply

qas.question: Voltage at the brushes is not equal to what?

plausible_answers.text: more current is drawn from the supply

qas.question: If load decreases, what happens to current drawn?

context: Since the armature windings of a direct-current or universal motor are moving through a magnetic field, they have a voltage induced in them. This voltage tends to oppose the motor supply voltage and so is called "<a0_0><b4_0>back electromotive force<b4_0/><a0_0/> (emf)". The voltage is proportional to <a1_0>the <b5_0>running speed of the motor<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The <a2_0>back emf of the motor, plus the voltage drop across the winding internal resistance<a2_0/> and brushes, must equal the voltage at the brushes. This provides the fundamental mechanism of speed regulation in a DC motor. If the mechanical load increases, the motor slows down; a lower <b6_0>back emf results, and <a3_0><b7_0>more current is drawn from the supply<b7_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/>. This increased current provides the additional torque to balance the new load.
